This is a servo mount adapter.  I was modifying a R/C car.  I needed to switch out the 4-wire motor controller up front for a 3-wire servo (in this case, an HS-322 HD), but the original control was screwed in vertically while the servo needed horizontal fasteners.

• Modify file as needed for the size of your servo and for the vertical risers.
  • Print out mount.
  • Screw in servo to the horizontal section. I had to use spacers on the screws here.
  • Screw the adapter down to the vertical risers.

QX11-MAGA U-Post Support

This is a PRACTICAL example of stuff I do all the time with my 3D Printer. The chances anybody needs this thingy is REMOTE, but you can certainly download and study it, and maybe adopt it to a use you have.

I am putting up a Dog-Fence with 6’ U-posts (4’ when in ground) and welded wire fencing.
The corner posts need to be supported at the corners to act against the force of the fencing.
I have some 6’ sections of ½’ Galvanized Pipe around, and an 1-1/4” Diameter custom cut closet rod, so I’ve designed an adaptor that supports my corners using these dimensions.

The Corner Post Adaptor Fastener Hole is for a ¼”-20 bolt through. 6mm is a tight fit, and you’ll have to drill out the hole in the U-Post to accommodate the slightly larger 6mm machine bolt.

If you’re digging the vibe, here’s my parts list:
U-Posts: https://www.lowes.com/pd/Blue-Hawk-Common-5-in-x-6-ft-Actual-0-6-in-x-5-in-x-6-ft-Powder-Coated-Steel-U-Post-Post/4780967
Closet Pole: https://www.menards.com/main/storage-organization/closet-organizers/closet-organizers-accessories/john-sterling-4-platinum-closet-pole/p-1444436938837-c-12650.htm?tid=4844601706196273649&ipos=5
Galvanized ½” pipe: https://www.lowes.com/pd/Southland-Pipe-1-2-in-x-72-in-150-PSI-Galvanized-Pipe/1000228013

And if you hit a buried ½” copper tubing PROPANE line, this can come in handy: https://www.menards.com/main/plumbing/rough-plumbing/pipe-tubing-hoses-fittings-accessories/fittings/brass-fittings/brass-compression-fittings/1-2-od-lead-free-straight-compression-union/p-1444442651685-c-9433.htm?tid=5634849103712204788&ipos=2

But the real idea here is to design your adaptor to accommodate what you have, or can easily and inexpensively obtain! My set-up is quite sturdy, I must say!

There are holes in the U-Posts that I am going to use to my advantage to secure the corner-brace for the 3-D printed Galvanized-Pipe adaptor. The angle to accomplish my task is 57 degrees out from the post, 33 degrees about the plane of the ground. I’m cutting the 1-1/4 Closet Rod into 1’ lengths to use as stakes to secure the ground side of the 6’ Galvanized-Pipe supports. My corner supports have clearance for the plastic Thread-Protectors on the Black-Pipe. You never know when I might have to steal one for a different project!!!

I made these out of PLA. I would recommend using ABS or something NOT biodegradable because this is an outdoor project. Anyway. It’s what I had.

I created the Bodies in FUSION 360. I’ve exported the bodies as separate STEP files that you may use for manipulating in a CAD environment. Have fun, and MAGA, one Thingi at a time!

-This was sliced and coded using ReplicatorG employing 2 shells (3 total) using PLA.

  • FlashForge Creator Pro (Similar to Makerbot Replicator 2)
  • Heated Bed 45 Celsius
  • Blue Painters Tape on bed, no further treatment
  • Print Temperature 220 degrees Celsius
  • Use supports No rafts for PLA.
  • Feedrate 40 mm/s
  • Travel Feedrate 55
    (If anybody has more optimum feedrates, please share!)

REQUEST: Please help me improve my sharing! STEP files have proven reliable for me to transport file between different CAD platforms. If STEPs are a problem for you, please let me know what other common and relatively generic Cad format works better for you.

description.text: Used to hold up shelves in a cupboard or cabinet.

I purchased a used CycleOps Fluid Bike Trainer and it was missing the left interior bushing, causing the skewer clamp to drop/wobble. This replaces it nicely.

Nothing too special for printing. I secured it into the trainer using some hot glue, as the 'ram' is still somewhat tight in the opening, and will push the busing out if left loose. The ram on my trainer is 1 inch in diameter, opening in bushing is 1.02 inches - it needed to be as tight as possible to hold it 'center' in the opening with no play. This does the job.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: Tried a couple on here and they didn't work or were too weak. But after I fixed the threads, rotated them, scaled them, changed the pitch slightly added a recess for the nose of the Dremel erased the rest of the object and made an entirely new object MSKA's Dremel protector was perfectly usable. When tight the buttons on your Dremel also point out which is pretty important. I posted the SketchUp file too so you can mod it as needed. It's manifold and prints flat. Enjoy! Please note the recessed ring at one end of the threads points towards the Dremel.

A Stand for a Tablet which works in Portrait or Landscape.  
My buddy Rob has a Dell Venue 8 Android tablet which also lives in a big leather case. He wanted to be able to plug the power in (bottom left) while it also sat in a stand, and didn't want to have to take the tablet out of it's case... the cast + tablet is thick, so required a hefty depth to the stand... this is 22mm (just over 3/4") deep, so allows space for the tablet and case.

title: Hypercube Evolution Breakout Board Holder for hot end wiring
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I created this as a way to be able to change out Hotend cartridges easily. I am still building my printer but the way this works is you build the carriage you need and mount it to Scott's X Carriage. Then you fit in one of these http://www.mdfly.com/products/dual-rj45-ethernet-connector-breakout-board-spring-leaf-8p8c-w-led.html

Leave enough wire so you can slide the board up to get to the release screw and then you can take the whole thing off (Leave this holder mounted) Pop on your new mount with it's own board and change any settings and go.

You could also just use this for a nice clean wiring solution. WORD OF CAUTION>>> DO NOT USE THIS FOR YOUR HEATER CABLES> THEY NEED A STRONGER CONNECTION!!!. Way too much Amperage for an Ethernet cable.

I created a two and 4 hole version. I have not been able to test yet but it should work fine.

description.text:
This is not a USB mass storage device!
It's a modified Teensy LC or Teensy 3.2 microcontroller that can be used to send keystrokes to a computer/phone/tablet at around 6000 words per minute as though it were a USB keyboard. Of course, that's not all it can do!

Modifying The board:
I have cut the board width down to ~14.85mm by cutting and filing the portions of the board where the through holes were. If you do this, be careful not to cut the traces that go from the USB 5v input to pin 26 and the rest of the board. I filed a little too much off and had to bridge the traces with some solder. The ground pin has a similar problem where the pin has traces on both the top and bottom sides of the board. If the bridge between them is cut, you can just solder a ground wire from the outer case of the USB A connector to the case of the USB mini connector. The nice thing about the Teensy LC is the "LC" - Low Cost. I bought three of them at $10 each, so I wasn't too concerned about wrecking one to learn "what not to do".

Adding a Male USB A Connector:
The male USB A connector I used was sourced from an old Kingston USB thumb drive, so I can't be sure that any others will fit this case without some modification. My best guess would be this USB A connector from Sparkfun. It seems to have the right dimensions, but the solder pads are further to the rear of the connector. Some heat shrink tubing should be enough to insulate them from shorting out on the micro USB connector, or you could try desoldering the micro USB connector from the board before soldering the wires from the USB A connector to the pads on the under side of the board. You could also try cutting the insulation away from the shell of the USB A connector, further exposing the connector pins. Note that I have soldered the wrong wire colours to the USB A connector. I soldered the black to +5V (should be red), white to D+ (should be green), green to D- (should be white), and red to ground (should be black). It's not like the electrons know what colour the insulation is.

Programming the Teensy:
PJRC has built an add on to the Arduino IDE that includes software libraries, example code, and the ability to upload compiled code to the Teensy LC through their Teensy Loader. I have included a Windows example code file that will wait one second, open Notepad and type out a message, then fade the on board light on and off to let you know the program has finished running.

To upload new code to the Teensy, open the .ino file in the Arduino IDE, or create your own script. Click on "Tools" and make sure that the "Board" is set to the correct board (Teensy LC or 3.2). Click on "Tools" again and set "USB Type" to "Keyboard", then hit the upload button. When the source code is done compiling, the Teensy Loader will open automatically. Click the "Automatic" button to turn it off. This will prevent the Teensy from running the program immediately after it has been uploaded. Hold down the programming button on the Teensy board as you insert the device in to a USB slot on your computer, then release the button. This will prevent any code on the Teensy from executing, and make it ready to receive new programming. The Teensy Loader should recognise the Teensy board and now you can click on the "Program" button. When it is done sending the binary file to the Teensy, a message will appear that says "Download Complete". You can now remove the Teensy from the USB port and plug it back in without holding the program button, and the Teensy board will automatically run the code.

Enjoy your new keyboard!

This will help prevent your canon batteries from shorting out while they are out of the camera by covering the contacts. I made these because the Canon covers that come with the batteries fall off way to easy and also get lost easily. Another nice thing about this is you can print them off in different colors to tell the difference in a quick glance. I have my Official Canon batteries printed in white and my aftermarket batteries that I like to use in the battery grip printed in red. When printing make sure to have the closed end down like I do in the picture for the best quality. Also when you first use them it will feel tight but just put the battery in and out a few times in a row and it will be snug enough to stay on but loose enough to pull right off, however if you're using ABS or your printer is not 100% calibrated you may need to up the scale a little bit.

title: Lucy kwad - Parametric Miniquad Frame with agressively tilted body and arms for minimal thrust blockage

description.text:
Lucy Kwad

Is an innovative open source mini-quad frame, with an aggressively tilted body for minimal drag and positive life in flight. Lucy has been designed in OpenSCAD is paramentric, currently in iterative testing and can be followed here, on github or twitter.
Contribution are also welcome.

Lucy is named after Lucy Gonzalez Parsons.

OpenSCAD code and STL's can be found on the github page.

Updates

26/06/2017 Initial upload

28/06/2017 - I have spent the last two nights getting the code ready enough to print for the first (what I hope will be) flyable version. I got motivated when my motors arrived. I will print it out of PLA, it won't last long but hopefully I get an idea of how it will fly.

30/06/2017 - I have done about 70% of the build for the first prototype. I'm getting excited. I had to put the props on just to see what it looks like, pretty happy with the aesthetics :)
The PLA is definitely worrisome. Because of the design of the quad the arms are still rigid enough in the direction of thrust bit I'm worried about the torque of the motors during fast spool ups. If it expodes when I punch it I just hope it doesn't damage any of the electronics.

11/08/2017 Got back to working on this and finish the electronics for the first prototype, ran into some interesting problems. With the default PID's as soon the quad armed it would start vibrating and would generate enough lift form trying to correct itself that it would start to take off. halving the PID values didn't fix it, and neither did quartering them. Then I tried re-enforcing the arms quickly with some balsa wood (as shown below) and now it seems to fly well with halved default PID values. This is the problem with using PLA, I won't be able to tune it properly and therefore see how it will actually fly until I bite the bullet and get it made in carbon fiber. It's been interesting trying to get it to fly though.

I have only done line of sight hovering so far, I hope to take it for a good FPV flight soon.

15/08/2017 - A large update to the Lucy code just got merged into the master project on github. The change centers around the heavy use of the polyRound() function instead of relying on primitives so much. Snap shot of the work in progress below.

comments.text: Hello - How do you propose this will progress in 2018? Is it funds or time to bring this idea to full testing and maybe a v1.1 after prototyping?
comments.author: SnapshotHotshotInc

comments.text: It's mostly time that's needed. At the moment must of my time has been going to learning some webdev, as I would really like to build a landing page for this quad (plus it's a skill that I want otherwise). It is actually reasonably close to a V1.0, I really just need to finish a few things in the design where I'm happy to spend the money to have the base cut out of carbon fiber. Thanks for asking, it's nice to see there is some interest, I really have not got much feedback besides getting some likes and downloads on this page.

author: IrevDev

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:117519 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=117519

Using the following options: Text_Rotate = 0
Text_Font = write/orbitron.dxf
Your_Text = JEFF S
Text_Size = 8
A six sided die (d6), just composed of the axis

The die is composed of four parts, plus a smal square dot that should serve as a pip. You can cut this squre, glue it and paint it in any color you like to create a contrast with the die, or just leave the cubes open, if you wish.

I designed this six sided die from scratch. The idea was to create a simple, low cost and effective die. This version is composed of the pieces to be cut in a laser cutter on a 3 mm. MDF board.

The design of the die was done using Inventor, and then it was modeled on AutoCAD 2017 to create and export the .stl file. The .stl file was incorporated to have a reference on how to correctly assemble the die, since the pieces can be put in many positions, and only one is correct according to the design.

comments.text: An interesting design, with a critical flaw. It can land on its corners. If we look at the planes on which this model can land, it isn't a cube, it's a cuboctahedron.
comments.author: MCGarlick

comments.text: Hi, thanks for your comments, I will expand the comment I made in the solid model verion. I cutted, assembled and tested this wooden model, and it works pretty well, much better than you would imagine. The times it lands on the corner are very very few, and rolled in a padded surface, worked flawlessly. Also, good quality dice also fail to work from time time, landing unexpectedly on a side or crooked. I believe that in reality, this die performs in a correct way, overcoming what theoretically one think might happen. On the other hand, its simplicity and low cost are its assets, this allows to include this model in any board game laser cut board.
comments.author: MCGarlick

comments.text: I have never seen a standard d6 land on an edge or corner, so I will have to disagree that good dice fail in this way. I suppose if one simply treats a corner roll as "roll again" the problem is solved. On the other hand, if you use 4 planes instead of 3 you could make a true cube that never lands edgewise. The sides of the die, instead of being a +, would be squares around a pyramidal recess.
comments.author: 3BRBS

comments.text: I just meant that normal d6 sometimes do land crooked or on a crease, and you just need to roll again :] On the other hand, the geometry you are proposing, I think I wuold need to see and example, it's hard for me to understand it just witht the explanation, but sounds interesting... even though probably generating an angle -since we have an extra plane?- that you cannot directly cut on a laser cutter, wich was the original idea for this die. Maybe you can post a link to an image that resembles your description to understand it better.
comments.author: MCGarlick

comments.text: Again, I have never seen a normal d6 land on anything but a face when rolled on a flat surface. As for the new geometry, it would be less complicated than I was first envisioning, I think. The planes to be cut would be rectangles as in the second image on this page [ http://www.w-uh.com/posts/031123-more_cubic_bisecti.html ], and looking at it closer you wouldn't even need four of them. Two rectangles like this crossed at right angles would give all the points of balance a d6 would need to effectively never land on a corner or edge. The trickiest part would be working out the number markings.
comments.author: 3BRBS

comments.text: Thanks for the image. I think that the problem here, more than the number markings (hard enough), would be the mass center, that certainly wouldn't be close to be balanced.
comments.author: MCGarlick

comments.text: I thought there would be balance issues at first myself, but logically the center of mass of each piece would be precisely in the middle as they are regular rectangles, and when slotted correctly the two pieces would have the same center point. The number markings as well might be easier than we think, because only four "sides" share wooden egdes, so once you have numbers on those four sides worked out you are free to place the other two numbers on the sides with crossed wooden edges in any way you like.
comments.author: 3BRBS

author: cookies409

description.text:
To cover up any unsightly gaps, size this appropriately to your application, render and print. Depending on how you intend to attach it you may only need 4-8 magnets per ring (http://www.homedepot.com/p/Magcraft-Rare-Earth-1-8-in-x-1-16-in-Disc-Magnet-100-Pack-NSN0566/204721213), but I put holes for 32 for good measure. You can always reduce those or just skip some. I intend to use a paste laced with iron filings and I haven't tested its effectiveness yet. Also I didn't look up the correct spelling of "soffit" before naming these files. You can generate a new cross section using the provided php script. Be sure to manually add endpoints that will yield a flat bottom if your equations don't yield such naturally, like I did with [-12.75,0] and [13.5,0] at either end of the path.

I've included the means for generating a whole ring, a split ring, a sample piece for checking that the width is sufficient without wasting too much plastic, and a pair of sample pieces for checking that split rings correctly interlock.

You'll need https://github.com/openscad/scad-utils and sweep.scad from https://github.com/openscad/list-comprehension-demos to use these scad files.

No

No

description.text: I designed this after looking at other board mountable Picam fixtures.  This one gives you a tilt swivel.  It holds the Picam secure with 4 pegs on the inside and the back cover snaps on. (the back only fits on in one direction).  You will need some screws or something like that (I used header pins with heat shrink over them) to screw the camera mount to the board clip.  I may update it to eliminate the need for the screws in the future.It works well and still allows a bit of space to get to the GPIO pins if it is mounted over them.  Enjoy.

description.text:
The twins 3 and 4. They're made of garden gloves and do not speak. Instead, they communicate with the lights from their eyes. They're first encountered in the Library so I've made a book to use as a stand.

As seen in the photos, you can add LEDs to the eyes. Wires can be run down through the neck and into a cavity in the chest, that can hold small batteries. If you don't want to add lights you can just use the alternative face plate (without holes).

The finished character measures around 160 mm tall.
The book measure 160, 117, 14 mm.

You can find 9 and number 7 here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2039870
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2269813

title: MP Select Mini Fan Shroud Clip

description.text: A rebuilt, strengthened version of the replacement fan shroud clip designed for the V1 Select Mini by Jeffharbert. I found that the original version didn't hold its shape well in PLA, so I rebuilt the design using the same clip teeth as his, but with significantly bulkier, tapered arms designed to avoid stress risers. On my Mini, it's just thin enough to fit between the shroud and the Z axis tower cover when the limit switch engages, but YMMV.

title: Chiappa M1-22 Magazine
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
UPDATE 7/4/17
Change log: Redesigned feed ramp for smoother flow of round into chamber.

The original design did not allow the mag to be inserted with the bolt closed. This was fixed with a shorter and slightly wider spring plug.

A new follower helps the nose of the bullets find the breach at a better angle.

Happy Independence Day everyone! Lets all celebrate by blasting off some .22lr! Here's the new updated mag body, follower, and spring plug. I Ran 70+ rounds through two of these mags with 100% reliability. So lets hope I found the sweet spot! I know just because it works in my rifle, doesn't mean it will work in all of them. So be safe and mindful when using these mags. Also as a side note, do not shoot your rifle with the mag resting on a table, this causes the mag to sit to high and will cause jamming and possible multi-firing of rounds! This also holds true for the stock mags made by chiappa. It's just not a wise thing to do with this firearm and the way it's designed. With that being said, stay safe and enjoy everyone! Please contact me if you run into any issues.

UPDATE 6/26/17 I've ran into an issue with improper feeding on this mag. I have a new follower and an updated mag body coming soon to help solve the issue. I just wanted to get this message out to those who haven't yet printed the mag body. It can take hours and waste a lot of material for something that doesn't feed correctly. Also if you have printed this mag and have experienced any problems, please contact me and let me know. Updated files coming soon.

Aftermarket magazine for the Chiappa M1-22 rifle.

I printed this mag upright @ .100 micron layer height with supports (supports only needed for the retaining plate slot). I tried printing one at a .200 micron layer height and it does seem to work but sounds more like a washboard when the follower moves up and down. (.100 microns is much smoother) The rear locking lugs do not need supports. Instead, I added a 40 degree climb working up to them to save material and negate any need for supports. After the print is done, you'll need to cut the angle off with a razor blade, to make the bottoms of the lugs square for proper fitment into the mag catch. Everything is printable except for the spring, you may be able to find a suitable replacement at your local hardware store. I left out the viewing window on the side of the mag. Frankly, I never used it any way, and it's just another way for contaminates to get into the mag.

Removal of the supports can be a bit tricky, but not impossible. I used a dental pick with great success. Also a few spots may need to be trimmed up a bit with the razor blade just to help smooth up the followers flow.

I used Proto Pasta Carbon Fiber PLA for the print and its seems to be working great, Everything fit together very well with very little prep work. Also as a side note... The M1-22's have a set screw for adjusting the amount of play the magazine has while in the mag bay. This set screw may need to be adjusted for more reliable feeding.

I had been leaving my markers on the top of my whiteboard and they kept falling down. This was my solution.

It's a marker holder made for the Expo dry erase markers. This does require that you put magnets in it to function. Specifically it's going to need about 4 of magnets similar to these: https://www.amazon.com/Round-Disk-Magnets-Crafts-Office/dp/B000RB7E5Q/ref=sr_1_17?ie=UTF8&qid=1498370836&sr=8-17&keywords=magnet

they might work, but I bought mine at a swap meet so I'm not sure if they're exactly the same.

Also I padded the back of it with this thing: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00EE9LKRA/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 which is kind of awesome stuff. Neoprene, adhesive. You don't need it I just wanted to avoid scratching up my whiteboard.

Just a heads up, I was having issues when printing this until I slowed my print down to about 40-50% Then everything seemed fine.

Se trata de un robot educativo que los alumnos de diferentes niveles educativos pueden montar usando una impresora 3D junto con la plataforma Arduino. Es fácil de programar usando un entorno de programación por bloques llamado Facilino. Es posible adquirir un robot muy parecido a este mediante un kit en la tienda de Robótica Fácil: https://roboticafacil.es/producto/dyor/

Como se imprime y se personaliza el robot El proceso de impresión y personalización se lleva a cabo de la siguiente forma: Imágenes 1 y 2: Utilización del programa Repetier Host con las piezas creadas en TinkerCAD y exportadas en formato STL para configurar la impresión 3D Imágenes 3 y 4: Proceso de impresión 3D con la impresora "Leon 3D" Imagen 5: Piezas del robot DYOR fabricadas por impresión 3D Imagen 6: Creación de la plantilla con el programa Gimp Imagen 7 y 8: Simulación de colocación de la plantilla en el robot DYOR Imagen 9: Impresión de la plantilla en papel y pegado en cartulina. Recorte de la plantilla Imagen 10: Probar la plantilla montada en la pieza impresa en 3D con algunos módulos electrónicos montados Por último se pega la plantilla recordada en la pieza frontal del robot, pero esto no se hace ahora hasta que no se monte la electrónica, con lo cual se podrá ver en la siguiente sección (Electrónica y Montaje) como quedará esta plantilla montada.

ROBOT DYOR DETECTIVE

Curso MOOC EdX: https://www.edx.org/course/disena-fabrica-y-programa-tu-propio-upvalenciax-dyor101x

Portal de formación robot DYOR: http://dyor.roboticafacil.es

Blog robótica de la UPV: http://robotica.webs.upv.es

Twitter (@roboticaUPV): https://twitter.com/roboticaUPV

Facebook (robótica UPV): https://www.facebook.com/roboticaUPV

Montaje y conexionado de la electrónica del robot DYOR

Se ha mejorado el diseño original de dos formas:
1) Con la colocación de un conmutador para encender y apagar el robot
2) Usando una batería de 6V conectada a la entrada VIN del Shield del Arduino Nano

Se suben la siguiente documentación gráfica:
11- Montaje y conexionado de la electrónica – vista general
12- Esquema eléctrico del robot
13- Esquema de conexionado de Fritzing
14- Listado de componentes
15- Foto de todos los componentes
16- Vista del robot montado y conexionado – vista frontal y vista trasera
17- Vista del robot montado y conexionado – vista lateral
18- Vista del robot montado y conexionado – vista inferior
19- Vista del robot montado y conexionado – optimización de los cables
20- Vista del robot montado y conexionado – Vista isométrica del robot

Gracias.
Todas las piezas han sido diseñadas independientemente y texturizadas con Google Sketchup.
Este programa puede trabajar con tres niveles de renderizado si has añadido el plugin de Vray.
He usado el nivel medio de render, es decir, sin añadir los materiales a cada uno de los objetos añadidos, si lo hubiera hecho así cada imagen a un resolución de full-hd con un ordenador a 4GHz y una buena gráfica le llevaría unas 3 horas.

description.text:
My wife really liked this;
http://www.produktgesellschaft.de/en/bath-accessories/toilet-roll-holder-porcelain.html
but when I contacted the manufacture they wanted 250 Euro, 25 for the holder, 225 for shipping and handling.
I thought that was a bit much.
I promised I would make her one "like" it. I have updated the Front Center and the Rear Center to handle larger toilet paper rolls, if you downloaded these files and found that your roll was too wide you may want to reprint these and try again. I then added these to the complete model. I also set this as a work in progress until I print and re-try with a wider roll.
Depending on the size of your bed, print the complete thingi, or print the four separate pieces one at a time.

description.text:
Fidget spinner featuring logos for 3 of the Oceanic Pro League teams (League of Legends)- Avant Garde, Abyss, and Chiefs eSports Club.

This uses the spinner body by 2ROBOTGUY (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1802260) with different finger cap, bearing cap, and logos.

I used 608ZZ shielded bearings (8x22x7mm), and found I needed to scale the spinner body by 1.015.

Everything printed at 0.15mm resolution, 100% infill, with support as needed.

The caps come in 2 variants: one with an 8.0mm shaft, and one with an 8.2mm shaft. 8.0mm should be the same as the inside of bearing, but mine needed to be slightly bigger (poor Chinese bearings possibly).

remixed_from.title: Tilted Adapter for Noctua UPGRADE Fan + 2x Fan Cover

title: Tilted Adapter for Noctua UPGRADE Fan (remix for existing screws)

description.text:
remix of JKSnipers great tilted adapter.

change to the original design:
added spacers the size of the original fan. To reuse the screws holding the old fan in place ;).

some info collected so far:
The Noctua is a a LOT quieter: https://youtu.be/1zGFZx2_k2c
However the cooling is less effective and it adds weight.
See attached graphs (ambient 30 degree celcius; bed was not heated).
I'll update this thing if I notice issues printing (so far ... none).

Assembly:
taping the new fan to the extruder motor made mounting and placing cables easier.

Cabling:
connect red-red and black-black. Yellow/pcm cable tuck away.
Make sure after everything is in place Y-Axis end stop is still reachable fine.

--- update 26.6 ---
Fan:
any 40mm should do. Not sure if it should be PWM type.
Obviously the lighter the better.
The one in the picture and the test-video is Noctua NF-A4x10 FLX.
For reference, Noctua states on the package for 12V usage:
rotation 4500 rpm - airflow 8.2 m3/h - accustical noise 17.9 dB(A) - static pressure 1.78 mm H2O

Experience after some printing:

Still enjoy the quiter operation a LOT.
However, the fan used is actually a bit overkill since it is a lot quieter also than the print cooling fan.
A fan with a bit more noise and a bit more throughput would be optimal.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2

Notes:

Printed in ABS since positioned close to hotend at 50% speed with fan on.
Overhang side printed far from perfect but usable.
If placed in center of printbed and opened towards front then object cooling fan will essentially cool down the spot where bed thermal sensor is below and creates BED_THERMAL_RUNAWAY misreading. So place off center of printbed and rotated to prevent cooling fan to blow into the thing :).
this remix was my first time working with 3D CAD. Used tinkercad.

comments.text:
The original fan (30x30mm) has got 4.82mm H2O static pressure. So the Noctua (even the 20mm version) essentially is a hard downgrade.
What you would want is a 40x40x20mm fan with static pressure (this is what matters in this case) above or near 4.82mm H2O and ideally be less noisy than the original. This is possible, for example look at Delta EFB0412MD (make sure you use the correct part number).
Its 24db (compared to 30db original) and has same/better static pressure and cfm.
comments.author: lordofpackets

comments.text: Hey there @lordofpackets!
comments.author: lordofpackets

comments.text: Basically the PWM signal tells the fan how fast to run. As the printer cant supply this signal, the fan wouldnt know how fast to run and thus not run at all. This however depends on the fan. I've seen few PWM fans that would run if PWM is not connected, however they would always run at full speed. PWM fans cant be regulated by changing the supply voltage (i.e. dropping the 12V to 10V or alike). PWM is a Intel spec, can find the documents for this via google.
comments.author: jerry_nz

comments.text:
"The one in the picture and the test-video is Noctua NF-A4x10 FLX.
For reference, Noctua states on the package for 12V usage:
rotation 4500 rpm - airflow 8.2 m3/h - accustical noise 17.9 dB(A) - static pressure 1.78 mm H2O"
comments.author: Puddles1989

comments.text:
Absolutely agree. Found the 10mm version and used it. But as noted, the cooldown duration is a lot slower than the original fan.
The 20mm Version sounds like a better plan. The extra weight should be less critical than the lower static pressure.
That being said. No problems printing so far. I plan to re-tune PID settings though (need to find some time for: https://mattshub.com/2017/04/26/pid-tuning/)
comments.author: Puddles1989

comments.text: I have tried it with the 20mm thick noctua and tested it.

description.text:
I love strider086 design for an 3D printed Bearing Block, with those holes for M4 nuts. But it was designed for the IGUS Bearings, and I needed Blocks to fit the standart LM8UU. Thankfully he put the Fusion360 file up :D I downloaded the TestVersion of Fusion360 and redesigned it for LM8UU.

What I changed:

Block length : 30mm
Bearing Hole height : (v4)11mm (v3)11.6mm
Bearing Hole : Ø 15.3mm
Bearing stopper : Ø 11mm
M4 holes: Ø 4mm (because I also want the Screw to grip into the plastic)

  • UPDATE v3 --> v4 *
    I made a small mistake on the height for the hole (original btw too) v4 is now closer to the SCS8UU standart

Printer:

Malyan M150 (own E3Dv6 mod)

No

No

25%

Notes:

Depending on your printer tolerances, the hole for the bearing could be too tight ore loose. I made a tight fit, so that the bearing holds better. I used a second bearing as a pusher to press the bearing in. If its too thight ore loose, I included the Fusion360 file, edit in "Skizze4" the bigger ring +/- 0.1mm.

author: met

description.text: My first attempt at a 3D printed juggling club. Designed in Blender (just by manipulating a cylinder) and run through a series of filters in Meshlab (namely Poisson-disk sampling and Voronoi color sampling). Designed to print out one piece at a time and fit over a 3/4" dowel rod you can get at any hardware store. Printed on Makerbot Replicators, no supports needed. I want to give props to this guy http://meshlabstuff.blogspot.com/2009/03/creating-voronoi-sphere.html for walking me through the voronoi filtering process, it's much easier than I anticipated and prints out great. I'll be improving this design and printing out more (so I can actually juggle them) so stay tuned.

I printed the body parts at 100% infill and the handle at 20% infill. You're welcome to experiment with this and I'm still seeking advice on how clubs are ideally balanced.  
This took about 18 hours total to print.  
The dowel rod will require some sanding until you can slide the pieces on, you should sand a little bit, then try to push the rod through the peices. Don't sand it so much that the pieces move freely. The next design iteration will include stoppers that screw in to the ends of the dowel rod, but I wanted to get up this first prototype ASAP.  
Please let me know if you want advice printing, I'd love to see this design get distributed.

comments.text: Dube in NY has some nice ends and mailorder. How is the set progressing ?

comments.text:
Nice. Kind of looks like a numbers club. What are you using for knobs?

comments.author: BRdog

comments.text: I've dropped it dozens of times on surfaces a bit softer than concrete (linoleum floor, tile floors, earth, that compressed stuff running tracks are made of - a lot softer than concrete) - the same places I'd juggle with pro clubs and they haven't suffered so much as a scratch yet. Very impressed with the PLA plastic for this - PLA is more prone to snapping where ABS might just dent / bend but it's held up really well.

description.text:
Learning CAD exercise, inspired by a daily-life problem many other people have, if we look at the variety of solutions here related to that (200-800 projects).

The 1st version broke after 1 month, as expected for this geometry and print orientation.
The 2nd version take that constraint in account, the band shape being more robust and aesthetic (probably kid-proof this time). It is based on Siedi's concept, with two little improvements (hexagonal holes instead of circles and the spikes are closer to the 45° rule).

Here is the FreeCAD tutorial

https://www.freecadweb.org/wiki/Basic_Part_Design_-_Toothbrush-Head-Stand

This is a remix of FrankLumien's Screwdriver holder https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1322545

author: Kumardebu

title: Kossel Pro - improved cooling - 40x40 axial fan

description.text:
The nozzle cooler is designed for delta printers with E3D V6 hotends and offers improved cooling from all sides, preventing uneven cooldown of the printed layers. I designed it specifically for my Kossel Pro with a BL Touch autoleveling probe, but it should work for any printer with the specified hotend or similar ones.

This version works with 40x40 mm axial fans and it is an adaptation of the original design, meant for 50x50 radial fans:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2402116

The radius of the cooling pipe lets enoguh space between the 3D printed part and the heating block. However, I recommend that you insulate your heating block with fireproof insulation (you can find it in any 3D printer store or online) for 3 reasons:

  • To avoid the pipe getting heat deformations
  • To avoid cooling down the hotend and destabilizing the temperature PID controller
  • To avoid heating up the cooling air

The design uses 2 fans:

  • 30x30 mm axial fan for the hotend radiator (to prevent filament upflow)
  • 40x40 axial fan for print cooling.

The 30x30 axial fan is the one that was delivered with the printer. The 40x40 mm print cooling fan provides less pressure compared to radial fans, reason for which I included a cooling pipe version with bigger vent holes. Both are placed compact arround the hotend to balance it out and to avoid interfering with the delta rods.

This adaptation was suggested by a fellow maker, so if you think of any other improvement potential, please let me know :)

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

The cooling assembly has 2 parts:

  • Print cooling pipe and 40x40 fan holder (I included a version with no holes too, if you want to change the hole pattern and orientation / Version with big vent holes for weaker fans)
  • Radiator fan holder

I designed them as two separate parts to be easier to print without suports. They are mounted together with a 2.5x10 mm wood screw, on one side, and a dove-tail connection on the other side.

For the mounting, you will need:

  • 1 * 2.5x10 mm wood screw (or similar) - to mount the two parts together
  • 2-4 * M3x 15 mm screws - to mount the radiator fan

Assembly order:

  1. insulate your heating block
  2. clip in the radiator fan holder
  3. come from the bottom with the cooling pipe, align the dove-tail connection, and screw it to the radiator fan holder
  4. mount the 40x40 fan into position
  5. mount the axial fan to the radiator fan holder
  6. adjust your PID (if necessary)
  7. enjoy your improved cooling

title: Z axis limit switch thumbscrew for Tevo Tarantula and similar 3D printers stylin and functional

description.text:
This should be a major improvement for anyone who has a Tevo Tarantula , especially as far as the z axis limit switch adjustment is concerned . I designed it for a friend who has a TT. The picture is taken of the back of the printer on the side with the Arduino board .

I haven't been able to remember what size screws were used . the allthread was imperial not metric 10-24 I think . The screws and t-nuts to mount the parts to the printer are metric and were found among the hardware left over from building the printer .

The bottom piece will definitely need support material . I printed that one with the surface where it ends up contacting the upright of the printer facing the platen of the printer .

The knob is a different "Thing" . The funky knobby knob.

Video to explain more here
https://youtu.be/WCGyqG8JJS4

title: SQ8 Camera mount for Eachine Falcon 250

description.text:
This design allows you to mount the SQ8 Mini dv camera directly to the front top plate on the Eachine Falcon 250 and 250 pro series. I had this camera and wanted to find a good use for it, so after many revisions I have came up with this design.
the camera clips in place to the holder and so far stays in place also can be removed with care. hook the top clip in to the camera first so the camera is angled in the holder, then push the camera into the holder, then push down the camera into the lower cage.
the holder then slides onto the top plate it is a tight fit and the top plate needs removing first, also the holder may need a bit of drylube ptfe spray and working up and down the top plate first before fitting

The Fusion Design

After many alterations and test prints this is the final design at the moment.

Impresora modelo Tarantula A2 Impresora modelo Tarantula A2 Breve explicación

La impresora es de un amigo, según me dijo es el modelo A2 tipo Tarantula, los vídeos de la fabricación los realizó él.

Durante el proceso como se puede observar en una de las imagenes una de las caras quedó rugosa debido a exceso de temperatura durante la impresión. Pero no parece afectar a la integridad de las piezas.

Las piezas se han realizado con un 20% de rigidez como se indicaba en el curso.

La ídea es ahora emsamblar y decorar.

Exported with Fritzing 0.9.3- http://fritzing.org

Explicacion del programa de control en facilino.

En Facilino activo el bluetooth para recuperar los posibles comandos, los cuales son, modo autonomo, stop, adelante, atras, abajo, arriba

Si el comando es autonomo, se llamará a una función que lee el ultrasonidos y si la distancia es mayor de 35 avanza hacia delante con carita feliz, en caso de no serlo, para, marcha hacia atras y gira a la izquierda con carita triste.

He creado funciones para stop adelante atras abajo y arriba para poder ejecutarlas directamente desde la función autonomo como desde las ordenes recibidas por bluetooth.

El flujo del programa es simple, leemos los comandos, si el comando era autonomo, se pone a true una bandera y se llama a la función, en caso contrario se ejecuta el comando correspondiente, luego se repetirá una y otra vez este bucle.

Explicación del funcionamiento en app inventor

Como se ve en las capturas, hemos creado una serie de botones, el primero es una lista para mostrar los dispositivos bluetooth y conectarse al dispositivo, el segundo es para desconectarse, el tercero pone al robot dyor en modo autonomo, el ultimo es para pararse.

En un segundo layout hemos puesto los cuatro comandos de dirección, cuatro botones con flechas para dirigir el robot en la dirección que queramos.

En modo bloques se puede ver cómo funciona el código, en el primer boton en la función beforepicking obtenemos la lista de dispositivos bluetooth.

Cuando pinchamos la lista se activa el afterpicking y se conecta al bluetooth.

He preferido hacer una versión con Botones que me ha parecido más comodo de manejar que con el acelerometro, cuando se pulsa el boton se envia la correspondiente orden a facilino, (autonomo, parar, adelante, atras, izquierda, derecha)

En los videos se ve el funcionamiento.

Notes:

Make sure you use food safe materials like PLA, PETG or BDP.

The cutting wall thickness is 0.8 mm, so if you choose a 0.4 mm outside wall in your slicer, you should get nice results. It also helps increasing the extrusion multiplier by a few percent to get better adhesion between the walls.
Make sure to wash it well before use. If printed with PLA, do not use hot water, as it will deform easily.

description.text:
This is a flying extruder support for the Anycubic Delta printers.

The only thing to do is to dissasembly the standard support plate and assembly with the holes oriented to the back of the steeper motor. Then, just screw the whole assembly of the extruder to the flying support and connect it to the carriages with some rubber bands.

Now you will have a bowden tube of only 8 cm instead of 60 cm, more power extruding and capability of flexible materials.

Enjoy

remixed_from.author: kreidler
remixed_from.title: FPV Camera mount fatbee FB90 / CM275T on e010 0.4g (customizable)

title: FPV camera mount TX01 TX02 TX03 CM275T FB90 E010 and others

description.text:
Inspired by the newly published customizable mount generator http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2023426 I have had an issue with the size of smaller cameras. If you want to use the lightest option on a e010, H36 or similar every thenth of a gram gives you a longer endurance and lift.
Therefore I did a small quick and dirty optimization for the 3.4g Fatbee FB90 AIO spare camera from Banggood http://www.banggood.com/Eachine-Fatbee-FB90-Micro-Racing-Quadcopter-Spare-Parts-5_8g-25MW-48CH-VTX-520TVL-CMOS-14-Camera-p-1108072.html or http://www.banggood.com/CM275T-5_8G-25mW-48CH-NTSCPAL-Mini-VTX-600TVL-FPV-Camera-for-DIY-Micro-FPV-Racer-p-1102464.html. Thing is mentioned under remix: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2219651

Nevertheless the outer radii and and the internal fixing of the camera box were not satisfying to me. In this version 2 horizontal and 2 vertical stringers are attached to the box. Moving the box to the left, right, fore or aft can now be done still having the box attached to the outer frame. Additionally the outer radius can be changed by 2 variables to fit nearly to any quad.

I did not submit this thing to the customizer due to too many options which could be configured. So, please customize by yourselves.

Attached are 2 identical SCAD files expcept for with the camera size and the box angle.
Additionally some preconfigured STLs.

As you can see on the pictures it is easier to print the whole thing with 4 holes and cut the not needed fixing points while mounting. Final printed weight for the small cam should be app. 0.8g.

Update 2018-03-03: Added a hand-made 0° cam 45° rotated TX03 version for the upcoming hovercrafts / tinywhoovs. SCAD programming is not working correctly. Just quick and dirty adjusted

https://www.instructables.com/id/Marlin-config/

allow to configure, to firmware, operate with console
suitable for Windows,Linux,Mac
https://github.com/akaJes/marlin-config

Main features

  • instant changing of Configuration*.h files
  • quick help for Marlin options and Gcodes
  • compilation and uploading your customized firmware
  • console for access to serial ports

    Features:

  • automatically clone repository from github if you don't have it
  • instant changing of Configuration*.h files
  • allow to filter only changed options overall and for each section
  • show help for all options
  • show help for G-codes
  • show allowed options/gcodes depend to your configuration
  • reset configuration changes
  • switch between releases and update git repository from github
  • upload your old configuration over current
  • compile and upload the firmware to your device via PlatformIO
  • access to all serial ports using console manager (Linux/Mac with auto ports changing detection)
  • simple 3D tool for positioning printer head in console manager
  • snippets allow compose the BootScreen, calculate a step values for various stepper motors
  • quick navigation with a right sided menu
  • create an issue on Marlin github with your configuration

    Snippets

  • stepper motors calculators (belt driven, screw driven, extruder)
  • startup bootscreen preview
  • custom bootscreen editor
  • sharing UPnP helper with QRcodes
  • using your phone as webcam

comments.text:
As I know you couldn't.
But you can get information from it, which might make the commissioning easier upon the re-build
There some g codes, which you can send to the printer.
From about M500 to M503 which will write/read data to/from the EEPROM.
Also M92 will display the current step_per_mm values for each axis.
(Source: http://forums.reprap.org/read.php?1,624457)

title: Funky knobby knobs for fit on 8-32 or 4mm and 10-24 or 5mm threaded rod

description.text: Knobs I designed for Things I designed. The knobs thread onto the rod . The rod needs to be ground on the sides or roughened in some way first . You need to clamp upright protecting the threads then heat the rod with a torch or heat gun before screwing on the knob . You may be able to screw the knob on first then place in an upright position . The rod is heated to melt the pla just in the center enough that it conforms to the flats or marks in the threaded rod . Then let it cool in an upright position until the rod is cold . Then you have a threaded rod with knob on the end !

title: Raspberry Pi Zero (W) Justboom Amp Zero pHAT Enclosure

description.text:
For those who don't know the JustBoom Amp Zero pHAT is a Digital to Analogue convertor that sits on top of the Raspberry Pi Zero. This enables the Pi to stream very high quality audio at around 30Watts in a very small package. Simply hook up passive speakers & away you go. Many audiophiles have replaced large expensive DACs & Amps with this tiny set up its genuinely that good.

I looked for a printable enclosure but couldn't seem to find one so designed my own. The JustBoom also accepts a rotary encoder for volume adjustment etc (Of course this can also be done on the device you are streaming from) so have included a knurled knob for this.

Enclosure printed in PLA at 20%, Knob printed in PLA at 80% but I'm sure PETG or ABS would also be fine. Would suggest the RPi is stuck done with double sided tape & the bottom of the encoder insulated in some way as its purposely quite tight in there & we would want anything to short out.

I have no affiliation with JustBoom (Other AMP/DACS for RPI Zero are available) but here is a link to this board https://www.justboom.co/product/justboom-amp-zero-phat/

Feel free to remix, would appreciate it if you credit me, please no commercial sales, I have uploaded to help this awesome community not for someone to make a quick buck.

description.text: Domino set (28 pieces)

The "unconventional" spinner series continues. This time I was inspired by the rudder of the old galleons, which we have seen many times in pirate films.
To reduce the thickness, I used eight 6MA nuts, 10 mm. hexagon, and the bearing is, as usual, the standard skateboard 608, 22 mm in diameter. As always, it is not necessary any glue to hold everything together.
I downloaded two versions: one called "Timone_centrale", which is much more like a rudder, but needs supports, a bit of post print jobs, and a pretty accurate printer; and a "Timone_centrale_easy" that does not need supports and It prints easily.
The lids and the bearing caps are suitable for both models.

author: FelixTheCrack

description.text:
Elasticart is an elastic band of a thermoplastic and flexible material (rubberlike http://i.materialise.com/materials/rubber-like OR elastoplastic http://www.shapeways.com/materials/elasto-plastic) for the treatment of minor trauma, such as aching muscle, tendon pains and traumas for all those who demand immobilization or administration of a gradual release gel.
Being an object to wear is required a band custom modeling. according to the shape of the limb. Therefore this model is an example and is not valid for all. To detect the anatomy of the body part affected you may use a 3d scanner.
Here you can order the mobile created by Occipital to trasform your iPad into 3d scanner: http://structure.it
Alternatively, there are specialized centers where you can undergo a 3D scan to get the file from which to create the model; below are some of the selected centers in Italy:
  • Pescara: http://www.ortopediaimar.it/ricerca-sviluppo2.php
  • Policoro: http://www.nuovaortopedialucana.com/
  • Bologna: http://www.rtmortopedia.com/?page_id=408
  • Roma: http://centroortopedico2000.reha-group.it/test_computerizzati/scansione_3d_della_colonna/

I bought a while ago a plexiglass (acrylic) housing for my Raspberry Pi. This one broke during assembling due to bad design. However the possibility of opening the lid was very useful. Some time ago I thought I need an new housing and I can do it better. The way of assembling I used is different. I use screws and nuts to tighten the sides together. It doesn't break the housing and is also easy to disassemble again and to reuse.
Of course I added the RPi logo on the lid, This wasn't there in the original version either.
I've made the design in SolidWorks. The drawings are in the project. For easy use I made a Dxf-file of the laser cutter file for easy import. And I added a file for Laserworks with all settings.
The materials to use can be any material as long as it is 3 mm thick else the inserts won't fit. All screws and nuts are M3. The ones on the side to keep the box together are M3x12, but 10 and 16 mm will fit also. The ones in the bottom are M3x12. With an extra nut, so the Rpi has some space from the bottom plate.
The lid can open and close very easily so you can access the part for experimenting.

title: Session Mount for BULLIT Drones Xcaliber frame

description.text:
Just a slightly different session mount, made to fit the BULLIT Drones Xcaliber freestyle frame perfectly. Just use zip ties to secure it to the top cam plate. Turns out it also works well on the BULLIT Drones BlackWidow (formerly known as the XR230 and XR160). Print out of flexible material. The ones we sell in our shop are printed from "SemiFlex" which works well. I printed my own personal one out of PolyFlex and it's fabulous.
This mount was designed for the GoPro Session, but it also works for the RunCam 3, and possibly will for the Foxeer 4K Box Cam.

Did you know that inside the tulle (see the picture with the red arrow) the power goes from two separate wires on the inside to a coaxial cable on the outside? Well, that's were the cable mostly bends (a lot) and so that's where it broke after three years.

Never had a worse laptop by the way than my 2013 15" Macbook Pro: over 10 dead pixels, broken power supply, bad sound jacket. Great design guys!

I had to cut open the PS with a angle grinder to find the problem. And then I had to make a case, because you cannot really open the original case without damaging it beyond repair :).

title: 608 Bearing Airsoft 6mm
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Yet another 608 bearing to be used with 6 mm Airsoft BBs. I wanted a round model to print instead of the blockier 608 airsoft bearings around.

Made in 5 minutes with Fusion 360. 4 mm center shaft, 6mm vertical bearing bore diameter (which have mostly been cut out), 6.1 mm horizontal bearing bore diameter. .05 mm extra width for each inner and outer bearing bore horizontal diameter.

I pre-selected 7 Airsoft BB's around 5.842 mm diameter for easier spinning. If you want tighter tolerances, choose slightly larger BB's

I tested various sizes and ratios and decided on this tolerance level for low rotation resistance and fairly little freedom of movement. I got the best outer bearing spin times with 6.2mm horizontal bearing diameter (.1 on each bearing for very wide bearing channel) but it was very loose and not needed for my use (filament axle spindles). https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2229433 is a good option for slightly looser tolerances but better pre-breakin spin time than mine.

title: Stanley blade printed label / heat shrink tubing trimmer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Using a 12mm/9mm label printer has its frustrations, they always print a load spare on each side so that the label comes out of the printer enclosure. I have never managed to cut these squarely with scissors so I created this.

It takes a good amount of force to cut through but it does work. Heat shrink is easier.

Parts:
2x M3 x 12mm dome head (to hold the blade)
2x M3 x 25mm dome head (side supports)
4x M3 nuts
2x spring 6.4mm x 10.3mm (or similar), I obtained this from Rolson set 61298:
http://www.rolsontools.com/150pc-spring-assortment.html

Obvious note: Stanley knife blades are sharp, use/assemble at your own risk!

Assembly:

If needed, clean up the holes with 3.2mm/6.5mm drills, be careful not to eat into the rest of the plastic body.

Carefully insert the blade and add the M3 x 12mm bolts and nuts to hold it securely.

Slide the M3 nuts into the holes in the base, add the M3 x 25mm bolts an tighten securely but not over tight.

Check that the assembly slides up and down cleanly.

title: Multicolor Filament (5 color) Extruder Feed Block for Bowden Hotend

description.text:
This is a compact 5 filament feed block manifold , that can accept multiple filament feeds from 1-5 extruders using Teflon feed tubes. A Clamping system is included in the design , to clamp the Teflon feed tubes at the inlet ports , so no need to fit the commonly used 4mm pneumatic fittings .
All Parts are produced in 1 print & are not subjected to any heat , as it mounts prior to the Bowden infeed tube .

The out feed port is threaded 1/8 NPT which fits a standard Bowden thread , using an 1/8 NPT joining nipple .
Alternatively a 4mm Pneumatic fitting can be used on the out-feed, & a Teflon joining tube to connect to a 4mm pnuematic fitting on the hotend.
While there are no 5 extruder mother boards that i'm aware of , the main use for this device , is to allow up to 5 filaments to be loaded at once , as extruders are very cheap on gearbest. Just switch the extruder plug prior to printing to select the filament that you want to print .

If you have a 3 color feeder system , you can retract the filament aprox 120mm , until it withdraws behind the manifold combining funnel , & then feed the next color filament back into the hotend.

The Manifold block contains small accurate filament tubes , so your printer will need to be dialed in correctly , in order to produce an accurate compenent. Dont use any support , as you wont be able to clean it out of the internal filament guide tubes, & avoid stringy filaments , like PETG , as string will also need cleaning out . Our prints are in Esun ABS Plus which bridges the tubes nicely .

You will need M3 x 30mm nuts & screws ( x 4 off) & a 1/8 NPT joining Nipple, ( avaliable from Hardware & plumbing suppliers . & the Teflon feed tube.
As NPT threads are tapered , they tend to split & crack the laminate lines inthe print , so a Split line is printed into the design , & held together with the M3 screws.
All the clamping components are marked with a dot , that should all be aligned during assembly .

The feed blocks being used on our machines are mounted directly to a bowden head & are working extremely well .They were designed for ABS Plus & shrinkage rates factored in . if you use other materials , you may need to add a minor scaling factor to correct dimensions.

I also have some mounting brackets for a diamond head
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2333015
But after using it for several weeks , i had a lot of trouble with filament back feeding the tubes not in use. I reverted back to the single Bowden head , & designed this manifold system , which works much better for my needs .
If you find this useful , please post some photos , & hit the like button .

28/6/2017 Added a youtube demonstration video
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YuY5K-6wZcI
This is a video of my 5 color extruder feed manifold working. I wrote a script for demonstrating the feed system . It extrudes 50mm of filament ,then retracts 130mm to clear the conversion funnel & then pauses 10 seconds ready for the next color to be plugged in . I ran each color twice , to prove that the stringy end that you get when retracting is still able to feed through the system multiple times without jamming , The first version worked fine with ABS , but it needed a little more clearance for PETG to account for the stringy end. This is the new version working with all 5 colors using PETG filament
If you have a 3 color motherboard , you can obviously program all this for 3 of the colors , but it can work as a manual color change with the standard Anet motherboard as per the demonstration .

Update 11/7/2017 Added some extra files , separated the clamps so they can be printed separately ,
Opened the filament holes in the manifold block from 2mm to 2.6mm which allows filament with a stringy end or enlarged bulb end to feed easier without jamming . Make sure the short Teflon feed tube to the bowden head has a nice internal chamfer , that can be cut with a sharp blade.This version seems much better.

comments.text:
Hi , I haven't actually made any FW changes , just running standard Marlin Firmware .
As you can see in the video i'm swapping extruder plugs manually for the color i want .
I have a new motherboard with some extra extruder drivers, but i havent installed it yet.
I realised that i never print in multicolor. I just like the manifold block as i have 5 colors loaded into extruders & ready to go when ever i want & all i have to do is swap plugs .
The extruder retraction is just done in the Cure printer direct control box . You just type in the Gcode retraction script manually .
The automated script i ran in the video was the same , i just typed it into the G code start code script to run the demo automatically.
I dont even have a copy , as i just deleted it after the demo.
All you really need is something like

description.text:
Holder for BluCon Nightrider, I don't have Nightrider myself yet, please print it and test if it fits, let me know what has to be changed.
The strap opening is 21mm wide.

Inside diameter 35.65mm

Made 3 new designs, V2 20mm and 25mm, V3 25mm which may be not easy to print.

V3 35mm print upside down with support.

comments.text: Will do, thank you.
comments.author: robarthur

comments.text: We have now printed a couple of the straight strap mountings and they work well. The angled mountings were too weak on the sides, but the straight one seems to work fine. We are actually running the strap right across the top of the holder, to make sure we don't strain the strap mountings. We tried annealing one in the oven (1 hour at 100 degrees C), but it shrank. We might try again, but with a lower temperature. This may make it more resilient. Great job. We're just using the 25mm version for the Blucon. Thank you so much for your work on this.
comments.author: robarthur

comments.text: yes, annealing will shrink, measure how much it shrunk then resize the original prozentual to compensate the shrinkage.
comments.author: robarthur

comments.text:
We've made a couple of these. The design is superb and the fit around the blucon is perfect.
However, both our prints suffered from the same problem.
The edge of the strap holder is too weak. It just breaks with no strap on it. There is no way it would hold a strap.
I think it would have to be, maybe four times as thick.
I think the strap would be safer to go right across the top of the hole, so you aren't relying on the little strap holders to keep it in place.
That means it just needs a single slot for the strap to go through, each side, not a double slot for the strap to wrap around.
Even so, it would still need much stronger sides to the slot.
Overall, it is an excellent project, and very close to something that would be really useful for us.
Thank you so much for your efforts so far.
comments.author: robarthur

comments.text:
sorry for the late reply, missed your comment.
Are you talking about the one with the angled strap mounting?
you may have to tweak your printer settings for better layer adhesin as I see some drooping.
also, print it upside down with maybe extra part cooling fan, then no support needed.
I printed few of this w/o any problems and they are still holding,

description.text:
This is a security piece for the new security approvals of the german shooters confederacy (Deutscher Schützenbund - DSB), in which you´ll have to cover all chambers of your revolver during transport or when laying your gun down. Who the f____ made this approval??
Due you don´t see if there are bullets in the chambers while they are covered with this damn thing, my design has hollow pins to go into the chambers, so you can see that they are empty. The red flag has a hole to mount an even bigger red flag if your nitpicking supervisor thinks that it´s not big enough to see. rage

This design fits the Smith and Wesson model 686, by the way.
EDIT: Also seems to work with Colt Python (Thanks, Zetif)

V2 is a version without holes, just with short dummy cartridges. Some Pictures show Version 1, that was a bit too wide but worked the same way

description.text:
My version of the RaspberryPi Case with magnets for the RaspberryPi Zero. This is an similar design as my A+ case http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:580757 or my RPi 2,3 case https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:688135
The RPi is held in with M2.5x6mm screws in the bottom shell. The screws are directly bolted into the plastic. I usually make sure that the holes fit the thread by drilling it with a 2.2 mm drill.
The top attaches to the bottom by 4 magnets. With that I am able to achieve that there is not a single screw, fastener, etc. on the outside of the case.
There are four options for hiding/opening the camera, gpio, hdmi or the usb connector. If you need a different stl or another modification, please contact me.

The magnets are 4mm in diameter and 4mm in height. I purchased mine from supermagnete.de with part number S-04-04-N
The M2.5x6mm are purchased from rs-components
http://at.rs-online.com/web/p/maschinenschrauben/0560552
Make sure that they are steel, otherwise the magnet won't stick.
Self titled Godsmack is pretty dope, so I decided to make a Keychain.....

title: CHOE Qi Wireless Charger Stand (Optimized for Nexus 5 & 7)

description.text: A wireless charging stand I designed for my Nexus 5 & 7 devices. It is designed to work specifically with the CHOETECH Qi Wireless Charging Pad, available from Amazon The charging pad fits snugly into the recessed slot and includes a strain relief groove for the USB cable on the back. It should work with other Qi wireless compatible devices, depending on their size and placement of the charging coil. The bottom of the pad is situated 20mm from the bottom edge of the device and it should fit device with case, up to 14mm thick.

Printed on MakerBot Replicator 2 in PLA. Layer Height: 0.25mm
Infill: 10%
Shells: 3 Print took about 6 hours.

author: ManiacalLabs

title: Tevo Tarantula X axis belt tensioner

description.text:
An usual complaint about the Tarantula is that the X axis belt is not parrallel to the axis, leading to some Y movement on the carriage.

This Thing solves it by adding adjustable idle pulleys, made of 608 bearings.

A first iteration used pulleys like the Y axis ones, but they were of really poort quality and not turning on their axis, thus de 608 solution.

You'll need to print a pair of those brackets and provide two 608 bearings, and four M4 screws with the appropriate T nuts

The end of the shaft also allows to put an M4 screw with a 4x12mm washer, but it shouldn't be required as the 608 sits quite firmly on the shaft.

title: Fan Shroud/Radiator Mount for 3 optical drive bays

description.text:
This thing allows one to mount a 120mm fan with 120mm sized radiator in 3 optical bays.
Also it serves as a small 5mm shroud.

I use it to mount a 240mm radiator in the bottom 6 bays of a CM Storm Stryker, and have the upper 3 bays free from the interference with the radiator upper part.

The design can be customized to allow for different fan shift and mounting hole positions.
Looks like 140mm fan or rad can be fitted too, but only on one side of the mount.

author: cornocb22

title: Aquarium filter replacement clamp for Fluval FX5/FX6

description.text:
If you have a Fluval FX5 or FX6 filter you probably at some point had to replace one of the clamps. these things are expensive ($12.99 on Amazon for 1 clamp and there are 8 clamps). This STL model is for a replacement for the plastic cylinder that fits at around the hex head of the bolt which is what normally breaks. you can try to reuse the existing bolt and nut but if they are stripped like the case was with mine you can pick up replacements from Home Depot or Lowes. here are the ones that worked for me:

Bolt: M5-.80 x 40
Nut: M5-.80

Enjoy

description.text:
Made this modular tool holder to keep my tools (screewdrivers, hex drivers, calipers, pliers, hammer, etc.) organized on my desk.

It was designed to be installed on my office, in a 25 mm gap between two wood pannels, without fasteners. I added a backside hole later, so that the modules might also be wall mounted using some screws (actually I didn't test this method).

Instructions on how it was designed at https://www.instructables.com/id/3D-Printed-Tool-Hanger/

Did you know you can buy an Anet A8 only $165.99? Get yours at Gearbest:

title: bigBot
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: A big RepRap style 3D Printer. The current build volume is about 700x700x500mm - where this needs to be improved since the footprint is more than 1mÂ³. Have a look at http://blog.teil3.ch/category/Hardware/bigBot (german) Watch printing https://vimeo.com/42721328 Get all the project files (inclusive scad): https://github.com/teil3/bigBot

This is still Work in Progress. It DID work but there are still several problems. The Z-Axis is losing Steps and wobbles.
It will also take some Time to complete the BOM and the Instructions. It uses http://www.makerslide.com/ the Open Source Linear Bearing System. I use RAMPS1.4 and Marlin to drive it.

This thing is an enclosure for filament filter thant can be attached to any edge that is 10mm wide. It has aditional printable screw that can be used to firmly lock it in place. The filament filter has a hole designed for PTFE tube (with a hole for optional M3 screw to lock tube inside or to easily glue it in).
The filter itself is best printed upside-down and that way it will need only small amount of supports that are easy to remove (as you can see on pictures). I printed mine in PET-G and after removing supports it came out really nice (as the pictures show).

comments.text: What is a filament filter??
comments.author: cwaa

comments.text: It is used to hold a piece of material (such as a sponge) that wipes dust and small particles from the filament. You can also drop a few drops of mineral oil on the sponge to lubricate the filament before it enters a long PTFE tube to reduce friction, but I haven't tried oiling since I don't use long tubes.

description.text:
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1657791

Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=1657791

Using the following options:

GenerateBaseSupport = yes
SupportDistance = 0.3
SineCutoutHeight = 1.5
mHeight = 30
mXDistance = 15
SupportHeight = 5
mXCount = 1
mDiameter = 18
FlatBottom = yes
SuperEllipsePower = 1.5
Preset = 0
mRotation = 45
mYCount = 1
mYDistance = 15
WallThickness = 1.5

This actually works. I usually just slightly dent the side of the can before crushing, because it makes it a LOT easier to crush. There is no reason to print the Can, it is just included to help visualize where it goes.
This was sized to almost exactly fit the size of my print bed. I had to print the handle with the gears vertical, and the handle laying down (at an angle) in order to fit it. Some of the teeth didn't print properly, but those teeth were not actually used.
I didn't mark this as configurable yet, as I have only ever tried the one set of settings.
This requires two ball bearings where the handle/gear meets the top piece that slides up and down. You will have to measure the bearings that you are using to make them fit, the dimensions are in the .scad file.
When assembling the unit, insert the handle such that the handle is almost horizontal when on an uncrushed can, you need the leverage. (not the way it shows in the file).
Also make sure to lubricate the top slider using vaseline or grease.

It does not crush the can as flat as some can crushers, it basically gets it down to about 20-25% of the full size.

Each part was taking 15 hours to print, and I got bored with waiting so did not do a lot of experimenting with slightly better designs. Please give it a try, make some modifications/derivatives and insert comments.
I had fun making it, I hope you enjoy it.

Just added 2 new files. I changed the top piece so that it crushes the cans completely now. Basically I made it bigger.

https://youtu.be/dOc2pMA7Y2Q
It seems to be pretty robust, I just added a picture of some of the cans I have crushed with it

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30

Notes:

Support needed for Lever only because of the gear teeth.
I printed with 3 outside layers for strength.
The bottom piece was modified for extra strength as it broke right at the corner in initial testing.

title: Hand-Screw Clamp
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
get a sneak peak on my latest works in progress on patreon


This is a proof of concept of a new thread design which can make a hand-screw type clamp, commonly used in woodworking. It won't match the strength of an actual clamp, but I tried to make a clamp that was as strong as possible, with 100% 3d printed parts. For this, careful consideration needed to be made so that each part respects the grain of the 3d print. It is, however, still a 3d printed plastic clamp, so don't get too crazy with it!

See my process for designing this here.

Print Settings:

I printed everything with standard draft settings, in PLA. Through testing, I found that the small "SlideHinge" parts are always the first things to fail. They break off at the very tip of the end that captures the rotating knob. So if you wanted it stronger with minimal changes, you could print the "SlideHinge" part solid.



This is tricky to assemble. The design intention wasn't to make a simple clamp. It is more of a demonstration of a 3d printed mechanism to make this special type of clamp.

Also, adding some sort of wax from a candle / soap / etc. will help make clamping much smoother.





Assembly video:
https://youtu.be/MIiluSksuhI

Watch this thing crushing stuff:
https://youtu.be/ECYQ5PWOezY

description.text:
This was a quick project that was done for a friend.
In order to get progressive curves I used a for loop. I picked 1mm steps which is a little rough, but is a good compromise with speed of rendering. I might play with this later to make the step size configurable. After all it takes much longer to print than it does to render.

The basic idea is that water flowing down the water spout will hit the diverter and spread out instead of just digging a hole in one spot.

Print large side down and the downspout hole up.

description.text:
I have a 2nd gen Moto 360, and the strap for holding down the watch band kept sliding and would drive me nuts!
This is a preliminary design for keeping it in place.

Designed using fusion 360.

Folding

It is so thin that you will probably need to cut some excess off the strap. Basically, you fold one end over so it meets the other. They should come together so that it looks like one continuous peg. If it doesn't, fold it in the opposite direction.

Get ready for the eclipse on August 21st 2017!
Always be safe when viewing the sun through a telescope. NEVER leave the equipment unattended and make sure your filter is secure before pointing the telescope at the sun. Always inspect your filter for damage before use.

This is a solar filter cell for an Explore Scientific ED80 telescope but the filter should work for other 80mm scopes. Inner diameter of the cell is 128mm. Space between the inner wall and screw holes is 11mm.

Designed with Onshape.com. Printed with .4mm layer height and 25% infill using Maker Geeks 1.75mm Maker Series PLA at 235c.

Materials Needed:
SolarLite solar film from Thousand Oaks
4x M3x12 button head screws
4x M3 lock nuts
I also used two pieces of thin foam on either side of the filter material to protect it.

I used yellow for the outside part but I recommend using a dark or black for the inside part to block out light.
