title: Increased milling space for R-CNC, the printable milling machine

description.text:
I am currently building a modified version of R-CNC, the printable milling machine. Since the original design is too small for my woodworking needs, I intend to blow it up a bit:

Increasing the width is easiest: add 200mm to all the original measurements.

More depth is a bit trickier as sturdiness degrades by the power of two when just increasing the length of the side tubes. In a first step I will go with the original 25mm tubes but 1200mm length and then test bending. So just adding 450mm to all the orginal measurements. If bending turns out too bad, I will either swap the corner pieces with holders for 40mm tubes or I will add a second 25mm tube below - which is more complicated and less likely to happen. So the 40mm solution is already part of this upload.

Another simple solution might be to insert a matching flat bar vertically into the tube and glue it on the full length of the corners. Maybe just flooding the corners with epoxy resin.

Adding more clearance below the router requires stretching the x-fixations and shifting them upwards. All the original measurements are increased by 50mm, except the two side pieces which will probably need at least additional 80mm. Since the resulting X-fixation was too big for common 3D printers like mine, I cut the piece in half and added small hooks. You probably need to file the hooks a bit once printed.

There is also an updated drilling template for paper prints. You will need to scale it correctly: print it, calculate the required scaling factor by dividing real measurement on paper by the printed value. Then print the second time. Afterwards fold it at the designated line and place the fold at the front sides to mark the locations. Be sure to shift equally on both sides.

Please note that as of now this is work in progress and the one the or the other detail might change for better performance.

Update 2017-07-23:

I am mostly done ;-)

Contrary to first assumptions, a 40mm tube is too big, is covers part of the space for the belt. So I added a second tube with 25mm below the original one. Additionally there are screws in the bottom board to support the second tube.

This project now contains virtually all my files. Each STL is accompanied by a JPG of the same name so you have an idea about the intended purpose and location. I omitted the Sketchup files. Should you want them, drop me a note.

I hacked the Marlin files a bit to make the endstops work and to display the current state on the otherwise empty space on the LCD.

I also added support for a Z probe which acts as a second ZMIN for homing. Now I can wire up the router bit and place a thin piece of wired metal on top of my stock and have it homing.

Update 2018-03-04:

The sources with my modifications are all on Github

Since Marlin was not intended as software for a CNC, it does not understand every such gcode file. My current workflow comprises FreeCAD and the LinuxCNC or GRBL preprocessor. Just make sure, the output is not shortened as each line is required to contain X, Y, and Z-code like the following. There was a switch to accomplish just that bad setting, but I can't reproduce it right now.

G0 X109.8144 Y548.0000 Z13.0000

Since I am used to Sketchup, all the STL files were imported into Sketchup, modified and exported using the STL plugin.

Sketchup has a habit of creating huge and misleading output for at least Slic3r, so I ran all the files past the netfabb sanitizer at https://service.netfabb.com/login.php.

print_settings.Notes:: While the handle is printing, it's time to head to the garage (any plae with a cement floor) and take a hammer to any residual plastic from the original broken handle, remaining attached to the metal tool ends, clearing them of debris in preparation for insertion into your newly printed handle.

description.text:
Don't you just hate it when that 35 year old, vintage solder tool from your first starter soldering toolkit you received as a child - marking your first entry into geekdom - just up and snaps in half, launching shards of cheap injection molded plastic across the room?
At this point, you have several options. You can go to Amazon and Buy a new toolset for $7.50 that doesn't have that vintage radio shack feel, you could hop in the car, and hope the Radio Shack Store Locator tool on their website has kept up with the closing of more than 1000 stores, leaving only 70 corporate stores in the US. Here's hoping one is near you.
Alternatively, you can take the option I chose. I went to Amazon and bought a 3D printer then designed and printed my own replacement handle, so as to preserve that last vestige of early childhood geekdom that Radio Shack had stolen from me as the company and their products pass into the netherworld reserved for those companies consumed by the the ceaseless drumbeat of progress, smartphones, and Amazon.
It's with this in mind that I share with you a design that will likely appeal to only the narrowest of demographics - My replacement handle for RadioShack/Archer double ended solder tools.

Printer:

Malyan M200 / Monoprice Select Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.13125

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Ultimately the resolution won't make a difference here. There are holes in each end of the handle though if you print it as provided, on it's side you should be fine with no supports. I chose PLA rather than ABS as this is effectively a prying tool so didn't want something so brittle as ABS but ultimately either would work fine.

While the handle is printing, it's time to head to the garage (any plae with a cement floor) and take a hammer to any residual plastic from the original broken handle, remaining attached to the metal tool ends, clearing them of debris in preparation for insertion into your newly printed handle.

While the handle is still warm, secure each of the recovered original tool ends in a vise-grip and press each into one of the holes at each end of the newly printed handle. As the handle cools, the material will shrink slightly, and tighten around the shaft of the tool-end.

This is my nozzle changer for OpenPnP, the printed parts consist of a shim and a clip plate. The shim get sandwiched between two aluminium plates that I milled out on a Shapeoko2 and the clip bolts under the bottom plate. The whole assembly is mounted on 20mm M3 standoffs.
You can see the nozzle change in action https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IGgQiBn6JW8
In addition to milling the aluminium plates I also sanded the "tips" a bit to make slightly out of alignment insertions easier.
This is a simple openscad script and for the plates I used librecad.

title: Monoprice MP Select Mini V2 Flexible Filament Guide v2.6 - 3.5mm base, 3mm feed hole

description.text:
This is a remix of the great work of several gentlemen before me. This version is specific to the slightly different gap size found on the MP Select Mini V2 vs. the V1 unit, owing primarily to a nut of a narrower width, resulting in a larger gap to be filled by the feed guide. This version also cleans up the print slightly eliminating the need to bore out the feed hole after printing. You will still need to snap off the two front designed-in supports with some pliers after printing.
Entirely by accident, after I finalized this cleaned up design - because I wanted the part in black and the only black material I had was ABS - I found that ABS is a far more suitable choice for this print, than PLA. The brittle rigidity of the ABS helps in maintaining proper alignment, and the slightly larger feed hole used in this version eliminates the need for tweaking the filament guide positioning after installation.

Printer:

Malyan M200 / Monoprice Select Mini v2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.13125

Infill:

20%

Notes:

As this accessory/enhancement is meant specifically for the Monoprice Select Mini V2, it's worth pointing out the importance of optimal resolution as well documented on the excellent http://mpselectmini.com. It's also worth downloading Pronterface/PrintRun for your platform and reviewing PID AutoTuning before undertaking any serious work with this printer.

Snap the modeled-in front overhang supports off with needle nosed pliers then just drop the filament guide into place while compressing the filament feed spring/hinge as shown by jspooner or nuggyblake and you'll be good to go. The component can remain permanently installed for use will all filament, flexible or otherwise.

title: Modular Hydroponic System
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Just download, print, and grow!

My goal is to educate and empower the world to grow their own food ... one 3d print at a time! With this modular hydroponic system, you can do just that. The modules are interlocking, so it can be expanded and contracted in size super easily. I'm using the system myself and you can view my progress on Instagram @archipelagourbanfarms. I'm trying to grow all of my own food on my 200 sq foot patio. :) Feel free to ask me any questions. I'll be posting more photos as my garden progresses so be sure to follow!

If you want to start your own farm and don't feel like printing and/or would like to support my project, buy a starter kit HERE!: http://etsy.me/2CK7xeg

Miscellaneous Links:

Cropswap App: Buy, sell, and trade crops right from your phone! https://www.cropswapapp.com/

Precious Plastics: Open source machines, tools, and infrastructures to fight plastic pollution from the bottom up. For free.
https://preciousplastic.com/

The Venus Project: Today we have access to highly advanced technologies. But our social and economic system has not kept up with our technological capabilities that could easily create a world of abundance, free of servitude and debt. - Jaques Fresco
https://www.thevenusproject.com/

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Notes:

Printed on Anet A8 with a 4 brim using Hatchbox white PLA and wood PLA.

The top lid and reservoir require some sort of infill near the bottom of the print to print properly. I only have Cura so I printed those entire pieces at 20%. The module can be printed at 0% infill and be fine.

The only drawback is that each module kind of takes kind of a long time. I printing at 60mm which is about a 12-hour print. I'm thinking of experimenting with 80 mm and having the print time come down to approximately 10 hours. I'll let you know how it goes.

Holes needed post printing

  1. Drill 2 small holes on the outside of the top reservoir in order to loop a zip tie through it and hang it on a rack or stand.

  2. Drill 6 small holes on the inside of the top reservoir to allow for the nutrient solution to drip onto the net pots below.

  3. Drill several holes on the inside of the cylindrical structure that sits in the middle of the top reservoir. This cylinder helps to prevent overflow in the case of a clog or excessive flow.

The PETG should resist breaking that Alex says has happened on some of the funnels end pieces printed with PLA.  Printed great at 250c.  I am printing out a module in PETG and will post later.  All in all great design and the PLA and PETG fit perfectly together.  I am planting strawberry towers and will post when they are up.  Thanks Again Alex for posting this design. print_settings.Notes:: MakerFlex, printed from my FFC Pro since it is set up better for flexible materials.

description.text:
My Rostock Max V2 struder broke a connection, I replaced it with the new EZR Struder, and the bolts were the wrong length for the stock spacers. I have noticed how noise is transmitted up the solid attachment, and decided a flexible attachment would be better, so made some spacers out of MakerFlex. I would use the 15mm spacer on the struder side, and a 5mm on the nut side (have one between each hard connection). Helps with noise.

Even better if: The Stepper motor cut out on the Max V2 Extruder support is tight, meaning vibrations are transmitted up it. I am thinking of designing a better mount, one that better isolates vibrations. Of course someone could always make the model for me...

description.text:
*Update August 30, 2017 - I've made a small revision to the RingGear (RingGearRev2 taking it's place). I thought bearing slop was causing my spinner to jam every now and then but started to wonder if my circle while designing the ring gear came off plane and sure enough the gearing circle was slightly oblong (.14mm at max difference). So I've fixed this issue however I'm sure bearing slop is still at play. Next update will include fastener support! As the compression style fittings don't seem to hold up over time and they allow some play.

A planetary gear set made into a functioning planetary gear set fidget spinner!! This design uses five 608 bearings. Spin time and functionality will vary depending on the quality of 608 bearings used. For my build, I used 608ZZ bearings that were fairly cheap so there is a bit of play which at times causes the gears to misalign slowing down/stopping the spin. However even with cheaper bearings I average 10-15 seconds spin time. Even if spin time isn't long, it's a fun way to see how a planetary gear set works in the form of a fidget spinner!!

One fun thing to notice is how the outer ring gear will do four revolutions per one of every planetary carrier revolution.

Assembly instruction are included in the images. Any file with a letter X then a number at the end is stating how many of the file to print. Such as PinsX3.stl the X3 means print 3. Some fittings might be really tight as I found any smaller parts caused jamming issues with spin time (wobble and misalignment issues). For instance, the male ends that go into the 608 bearings are 8.6mm in diameter some 608 bearings might have a smaller opening but that wasn't the case for the ones I have. Light sanding might be need depending on different manufactured 608 bearings.

Oh, and apologies for the watermarks on the images but I'd rather not see my renderings used for commercial gain.

Printer:

Tronxy X3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1mm

Infill:

50% - 100%

Notes:

Print the SunX2.stl and PinsX3.stl at 100% infill and separate from the remaining parts which print fine at 50% infill. For all parts I used a shell thickness of 1mm along with a top/bottom thickness of 1mm. PLA was used for my build with a print temp of 194C and a bed temp of 55C. Sliced with CuraEngine.

Other settings will most likely work just fine but these are settings used for my successful build.
Check out the AssemblyInstructions.PNG on how to build

title: Calibration Block for Colido DIY 3D Printer

description.text:
This is a very basic thing - A calibration pillar to replace the awkward calibration card that comes with the Colido/Printrite DIY 3D Printer. Print 2 of these then stand them up on their ends next to the two Z screw rods and level off the platform as per the instruction manual.

You still need the calibration card to set the height of the nozzle tip, take your time with this as it is equally as important to get it right.

In my experience, a properly calibrated machine can print most things with little or no glue/hairspray. I only apply hairspray or glue for much larger prints. I also slow down the initial layer to just 10mm/s.

print_settings.Printer:: R1 ABS + PLA Model

description.text:
Spinner made to look like an AR15 bolt face. It is printed in 2 halves and glued together. Hollow areas give this asymmetrical part good balance. Since the end caps are bowl shaped, they are in 2 pieces that you glue together. Add a drop of black paint to the middle of the caps after gluing to make it look like a firing pin hole.

Gluing: Wash off whatever print-bed glue you used, then scuff the surfaces with sand paper. I lay the sand paper on a flat surface and rub the part on the paper. For the end caps I used gel super glue. For the 2 body halves super glue sets too quickly, so I used a very thin layer of clear 5 minute epoxy and 4 clamps. Each clamp squeezing 2 fingers together.

For the spinner body, you must have a bearing installed before gluing. I installed the bearing in one half then buttered both halves with a very thin layer of epoxy. I then mated the 2 halves together, rotated the halves into good alignment, applied the clamps and wiped the excess squeezed out.

title: printrbot simple fan duct and tensioner

description.text:
The fan/tensioner combo on the simple just doesn't really cut it for cooling.  This is a little more like the setup you get when you get the new one with the aluminum extruder.  The fan bolts will screw into the fan holes, just like they do in the wood version.  A small wood screw or two to attach it, and you are good to go.  
The replacement tensioner is two parts printed in place, with support material.  It takes some whittling to finish it, but it works, and has the added benefit of holding the nut.  
The duct doesn't restrict the flow down to a tiny output hole, or blow it out in a circle.  This is because fan ducts don't really work that way.  You really want to make it easy for the air to go in the right direction, or it will get it's own ideas.  
If you aren't sure what these parts do, or how they go on, you probably don't need this yet.  :)  Good luck.  We're all counting on you.

comments.text:
Actually, I don't remember. The prints I did were not pretty, but it worked. That was more or less the point, since I wouldn't have made improvements if the prints were good to start with. :)
You will find that, even if the fan duct looks crappy, it will improve overhangs and bridges so much that you could print a much better one with the same settings.

author: WildRoseBuilds

description.text: customized with 3D Slash!

This is a clip of an ac filter cover. If you have an AC unit in your home the has a filter that slides in the bottom it probably uses one of these clips to hold the cover on. The original clips are pretty brittle and if you have a tendency to force things like me this comes in handy. As not a single AC Dealer or Hardware store could get one of these clips and wanted to sell me a new filter cover with new clips. This saved me like 60 dollars and a lot of annoyance. For some reason when I drop this file into Simplify 3D the dimensions it shows aren't correct. This is designed to be 45mm at the longest part. So if you make sure it's set at 45mm for the longest face you will be fine.
https://youtu.be/qVtK-UF47yg

Using the following options:

line1_text = ONURHAN
line2_text = ZENGİ
$fn = 50

I've printed half a dozen of muzehack's
Failproof Fidget Cube (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2050830) for my nephew's friends, and they love them. I really like the model (although "failproof" is overly optimistic at best) but I wanted a two-color version, so I got to remixing. I started by making a 2x4 checkerboard mask in OpenSCAD. It looked great when printed, but since the hinges were now made of two different plastics, they tended to break at the junction. So I gave each hinge-half a couple of pegs that extended into the other half. I'm new at this so I have no idea if this is the "right" way to solve this problem, but I suspect that it's not and that I was trying to be too clever by half. I suspect that there's a simpler and more reliable way of achieving the same result, but again, I'm new at this. Regardless, the hinges seem much sturdier now.

title: Rose Tyler Dalek Blaster from Doctor Who

description.text:
I made this as close as practical to the original screen used prop from the Doctor Who TV series as possible.  It is however around 80% the size of the original (and still massive)  at 800mm overall length.   
I designed this from scratch in Sketchup Pro 8. Mostly using images captured at a Doctor Who expo in the UK I found on Flickr  
I made this as a hybrid CNC machined XPS Foam (blue foam) and 3D printed parts.  
Please excuse my feeble attempt at Rose Tyler Cosplay :-)

title: Iphone 6 Sonic stand speaker
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I printed one of these 6s sonic stands from Blackbird2016 and next thing I know everyone with an Iphone wanted one. So I decided to design one and not rip off his design before I start making them for other people.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1804269 This is the design that inspired mine. Credit where credit is due, it's a great design. I tried to come close to his design but my cad skills aren't what his are. I haven't printed one yet, waiting for another print to finish. As soon as I can i'll print and test fitment and make adjustments. Current version is a bit snug. I'll be adding a touch more clearance and upload the new version tomorrow.
Version 2 is now uploaded and should fit better. If you print one please post a pic!
